Intes

Forster Resonance Energy Transfer (FRET) has enabled the visualization of dynamic protein interactions, studies of protease activity, alterations in membrane voltage potentials and calcium metabolism within living cells. It has also allowed the conduction of high-throughput screening assays such as for quantification of gene expression. However, FRET is confined to microscopy and it is becoming increasingly crucial to translate FRET assays to small animal imaging where the in vivo physiological context is critical for drug development, the study of diseases, and fundamental cellular and molecular biology.

The long term research goal is to establish optical fluorescence tomography, in particular FRET tomography, as a robust 3D quantitative imaging modality for pre-clinical and clinical oncology applications. As a step towards this goal, the research objective of this CAREER proposal is to test the hypothesis that quantitative whole-body FRET optical tomography of live small animals is achievable when patterned wide-field time-resolved Fluorescence Molecular Tomography (FMT) is employed. To accomplish this objective, the proposed research approaches are:
(a) Implement and optimize patterned light strategies for multispectral time-resolved optical tomography;
(b) Create new strategies for fast and robust FRET optical reconstructions based on time gates, Monte Carlo forward model reconstruction algorithms and graphical processor unit (GPU) computational architecture;
(c) Establish FRET tomography in live animals by imaging NIR-Transferin labeled FRET pairs co-internalized in cells, implanted in live animals and quantify the donor fraction experiencing FRET (i.e. cell internalization).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Optical imaging techniques are becoming central to molecular investigation of samples at the macroscopic scale with great potential for diagnosis or for guided therapy in clinical settings. Especially, macroscopic fluorescence lifetime imaging (MFLI) can be used to uniquely report in vivo and non-invasively on the molecular environment, enable simultaneous imaging of multiple biomarkers, and provide means to sense nanoscale interactions. A team from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute’s Biomedical Engineering Department has created a compressive hyperspectral wide-field fluorescence lifetime imaging platform that, unlike previous MFLI systems, does not require scanning or sequential acquisition of spectral data and is highly scalable in terms of sample size, spectral band, and temporal resolution.

This developed technology permits order of magnitude improvements in collection efficiency of spatial, temporal, and spectral data sets with high sensitivity, making it highly suitable for many important biomedical applications. This NSF-funded project will lead to new biomedical instruments for a wide range of biomedical applications such as optical mammography, functional brain imaging, pre-clinical imaging, and guided surgery for instance. The results of this project will also greatly impact the development of novel personalized therapies by enabling the direct quantification of intracellular drug delivery as reported by lifetime sensing. Lastly, a set of dedicated computational tools has been developed and made available to the community. These tools have been widely adopted and will facilitate the practical implementation of 3D optical imaging of deep tissues. Overall, these research findings have been disseminated via the publication of 20 peer-reviewed journal articles, over 30 conference abstracts, 20 seminars/invited talks, and 1 Nature webinar.

In addition to providing transformative technical advances for optical molecular imaging, drug delivery assessment, and computational optical imaging, this NSF-funded project has supported a training and outreach program. On the programmatic side, this program has stimulated interdisciplinary interactions between the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute Schools of Engineering and Science, Albany Medical College, Massachusetts General Hospital, University of California Los Angeles, Lawson Health Research Institute, and Ecole Polytechnique de Montreal. On the educational side, it provided educational and research opportunities for under-represented minorities, strengthened the K-12 program with RPI’s existing efforts that are linked to our local schools, provided summer internships to high-school students, and reached over 150 undergraduate and 15 graduate students per year via the integration of education and research activities in teaching modules.
